WAR CABINET 145 (40).Italy.Suggested direct approach to signor mussolini.(previous reference:W.M. (40) 144thConclusions,Minute 6.)1. The War Cabinet gave consideration to a further messagereceived from, the French Government, again proposing that a direct approach should be made to Signor Mussolini.The discussion is recorded in the Secretary's Standard File ofWar Cabinet Conclusions.The War Cabinet :-(1) Agreed that an approach on the lines proposed by theFrench Government at the present time was unlikely toserve any useful purpose. At the same time, it was important that the reply should make it clear that in reaching this decision we were looking at the matterfrom the point of view of France as well as of ourselves.(2) Authorised the Foreign Secretary to send a reply to theFrench Government on the lines of a draft prepared bythe Lord President of the Council and himself, and readout at the Meeting (telegram No. 235 DIPP to Paris).United States of 2. The War Cabinet considered a suggestion made byAmerica. M. Reynaud that France and Great Britain should make an appealSuoo-ested to the United States of America for help (telegrams Nos. 281 andappeal by the 290 from Paris).Allied The War Cabinetn (1) Agreed that an appeal on the lines contemplated would tend to confirm American fears as to our weakness, andwould not produce the desired effect; and that, if anyappeal were to be made, it would be preferable to makeone on the lines proposed by General Smuts (telegramNo. 249 from the United Kingdom High commissioner in South Africa).(2) Authorised the Foreign Secretary to send a telegram to our ambassador at Washington in this sense, and askinghis views as to the wisdom of any such approach(telegram No. 938 to Washington).Richmond Terrace, S.W. 1,May 28, 1940.
